learning_outcomes.description: To understand and apply various software programs for analysis of biomedical literature and data
To create a scientific question and design experiments for testing a hypothesis
To critically evaluate scientific data and previously published work
To communicate research findings through written, oral, poster formats to diverse audiences
To work effectively in a research team, identify the characteristics of effective teamwork and critically evaluate personal and peer contributions to team processes

assessments.assessment_title: Experimental design and research practices test
assessments.task_description:
For this in-class test, you will be assessed on experimental design concepts and research practices covered in the first 3 weeks of the course.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This online Blackboard test will be short answer format and will be held during scheduled class time in Week 4 of the semester.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.assessment_title: Poster Planning, Production and Presentation Assessment
assessments.task_description:
For this assessment, you will create and present a scientific poster that critically evaluates a recent high impact research publication in biomedical science. The task involves identifying a recent research publication in your field, critical evaluation of the data and analyses presented in the publication, generation of a scientific poster summarising the key findings, and presentation of the poster to UQ biomedical science experts.

Further assessment details will be provided on Blackboard during the semester.

You are required to bring photo identification to your presentation.

As this assessment is marked by two or more examiners and a post-marking moderation process is applied, re-marks are not permitted.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your Assessment task, with the electronic coversheet available on the School's website (under Undergraduate - Assessment), to Turnitin by the submission deadline. You may submit drafts to Turnitin up to the due date, but you will only be able to submit once on or after the due date. You should also keep an electronic copy of every piece of assessment you submit.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

Your report should summarise the seminar's key points and learnings, critical evaluation of the research presented including techniques and innovation, communication and presentation style, as well as relevance to your research area of interest. The report will assess your written communication skills.

learning_activities.topic:
Getting to know you and resources for biomedical researchers

LEARNING OBJECTIVES:

  1. To promote networking and collaboration amongst student cohort
  2. To train students to work effectively in teams
  3. To familiarise students with relevant software programs to support biomedical research 


LEARNING ACTIVITIES:

SESSION 1A: Course overview; Honours goal setting and myth busters (with panel of recent honours graduates)

SESSION 1B: Brief introduction/exercise relating to GraphPad Prism, Endnote, Pubmed and Biorender; team activity exploring other useful resources for biomedical researchers 


Learning outcomes: L01, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Ethics, Integrity and Experimental Design

LEARNING OBJECTIVES:

  1. To be able to conduct scientific research in an ethical, integral, equitable and inclusive manner
  2. To understand the opportunities and responsibilities of using AI
  3. To design a scientific question, research hypothesis, experimental aims, and craft an informative abstract


LEARNING ACTIVITIES:

SESSION 2A: Ethics and integrity case studies (retraction watch) worksheets/class discussions; AI group task focused on equity and inclusivity in research design

SESSION 2B: Individual then paired work crafting abstracts, hypotheses, aims and experimental design using results stimulus 


Learning outcomes: L02, L04, L05
